div.p: 1. VI. Tuesday.

Call at Branch Bank U.S. and Letters to Midshipman Joseph H. Adams at Norfolk, and B. O. Tyler Philadelphia At the House; found Balie Peyton moving an Amendment of the Journal on the record of the vote of the House yesterday on the question whether Wise should be permitted to proceed—the Journal added, in his Speech Peyton had moved to add the words “in order.” After an hour’s debate, he varied his motion, withdrawing the words in order and moving to strike out the words “in his Speech”—which was agreed to.— Briggs moved the suspension of the Rules to receive Petition and Memorials; excluding the Motion yesterday offered by J. M Patton—which was agreed to— The call began with Virginia— Wise presented a memorial from an individual citizen of the District of Columbia, against the Power of Congress in the District of Columbia to abolish Slavery— Wise moved its reference to Pinckney’s Select Committee with instructions to report that Congress have no power to abolish Slavery in the District of Columbia, or the Territories. The Speaker decided that the motion was not in order from which Wise appealed—the previous question was called carried, and the decision was confirmed— I voted against the decision— Wise’s motion being to refer the memorial to the Select Committee with Instructions— Patton’s Motion yesterday was to refer the Resolutions to the Committee on the District of Columbia, with Instructions— I voted to sustain the decision of the Speaker that this was not in order. I asked permission of the House to give the reason of my different votes yesterday and this day, but objection was made, and I acquiesced— Wise then read with vehemence a Letter from the Governor of Virginia, enclosing the Resolutions of
the Legislature of Virginia, eight in number, concerning Slavery—the same yesterday offered by Patton— He was twice interrupted, by John W. Brown, and by Gorham Parks, on points of order, which the Speaker decided in his favour. Wise after reading emphatically the Resolutions, said he would not present them, and turned off from his seat and went out of the house— The remainder of the day was consumed in receiving Petitions and Memorials— The States and Territories were gone through— Jarvis told me the Story of what took place yesterday out of the House between Wise and the Speaker— He said the Clerk and the Serjeant at Arms were with the Speaker, and that Wise’s words were, damn’d tyrant—as I heard them the word was coward but I may have misheard— Jarvis rode home with me.
2: VI:15. Wednesday

At the house, immediately after the reading of the Journal the Speaker announced the unfinished business to be the Report of the Committee of Elections, and the motions that it be made the special order of the day for Tuesday 6. March, and for this day. There were motions that the Petitioner David Newland be admitted to a seat within the house, and that he be heard by himself on his Counsel— They were debated between Hard of New-York, Bynum M’Kennan and Hardin and others—till the expiration of the hour— A motion was made to suspend the rules, to continue the discussion which was rejected by yeas and nays 66 to 133— F. Thomas from the Committee on the Judiciary moved to suspend the rules, to offer reports, fixing the Northern boundary of the State of Ohio, and a Bill to admit the State of Michigan into the Union upon certain Conditions— This was carried and the Bill was read, and ordered to be printed— Then the New-York fire bill was resumed, and D. J. Pearce finished in an hour and a half against it— Altogether a very powerful Speech— He was followed by Amos Lane of Indiana, who after a Speech of 15 minutes moved the previous Question. There
was a call of the House, which after going through about half the names, was suspended— There was a second to the putting of the Previous Question, counted by Tellers, but on the question whether the main question should now be put the vote was 90 to 110. and this put off the consideration of the bill for this day— Then the House went into Committee of the whole on the Union, Jesse Miller in the Chair upon the Navy Appropriation Bill— Waddy Thompson of South Carolina made a Southern Nullification Speech against it— He spoke till half past four and then the Committee of the whole rose and the house adjourned— I dined with Mr Van Buren the Vice President—Mr Forsyth and his Son, Mr Walker the Senator from Mississippi just arrived—Messrs. Granger and Howard of the House of Representatives, Buchanan of the English Legation, Krehmer, Coll. Worth, Peter Hagner, a General Deniston of New-York, Mr Butler the Attorney General—A. H Everett—a brother of the Speaker Polk, Mr Van Buren’s two Sons, John and Martin, B. O. Tayloe, and several others— I had some conversation with Mr Van Buren after dinner, and remained after the rest of the company went away, with Mr Forsyth and Mr Butler till near Midnight.
3. VI. Thursday.

Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures, present, Adams, Denny, Dickerson, Holsey, Judson, Lee and Granger—absent, M’Comas and Webster— The Committee took up a Memorial recently referred to them from Baltimore for reducing a duty of 25 per Cent on Brown Linens— After some discussion the Chairman was directed to confer with the Secretary of the Treasury on the subject— The reduction of duties, recommended by the Secretary of the Treasury, in his annual report on the finances, was further considered, but nothing definitively done with it— At the House the Rules were suspended, to enable the Committees to report, and nearly two hours were consumed in receiving Reports from the standing Committees. I
I reported from the Committee of Manufactures, the bill from the Senate
4. VI:15. Friday

Mr Frye called on me this morning and had some conversation with me upon my private business, particularly respecting my Franklin Insurance company stock, the mill concern, the house near Van Ness’s and other matters— He will attend the Meeting of the Company next Monday, to apply for a renewal of their charter— Mr Connelly brought me 6 numbers of the aboriginal Port-folio, containing Portraits of Indians. I called on the Secretary of the Treasury, to make enquiry concerning the memorial from Baltimore for the repeal of duties on Brown Linens— He said he would send me this day copies of his correspondence.— He spoke of the distribution of the expenditures in the different parts of the Union and referred to me a Document of the last Session of Congress N. 27. a Report of his— At the House, the contested Election in North Carolina David Newland vs James Graham was resumed and the question whether he should be allowed to support his claim by himself or by counsel was debated till one— Then Bynum moved that the house should proceed, without taking appropriate business the vote was 87 to 83. and the Speaker decided that two thirds were necessary to set aside private Bills— Bynum appealed and a debate of two hours ensued, on the 19th. and 106th. rules—the previous question was called and carried, and the decision of the Speaker was confirmed 131 to 63— Private Bills were taken up at 3— The House adjourned at 4.— Mr Gurley, came with

two Poles, who have a Bill before the house to authorise the Polish exiles, to whom lands were granted by the last Congress to sell the Lands— They asked my aid for the passage of the Bill— They wish also
5. VI. Saturday

A. H. Everett called upon me this morning, and said there was a Mr Schermerhorn, a Clergyman of New-York, who had been employed in some of the Negotiations with the Indians, and was quite intimate and confidential with President Jackson, and who had mentioned to him the wish that there should be some reconciliation between him and me— Everett did not understand that the President had spoken of it to Schermerhorn, but that he would speak of it to the President, if I was willing— I desired Mr Everett to thank Mr Schermerhorn for his kind intentions but very explicitly to decline giving any authority from me to make an advance of any kind towards the President— That if ever any personal intercourse between him and me is to take place, which I neither expect nor desire, but would certainly not repel, it must come from him— He placed himself deliberately and wantonly in that position, when far from having ever given occasion for it, I had rendered him important service which he had personally acknowledged; and if he has any disposition to change it, he must change it himself.— Mr Schermerhorn is an entire Stranger to me; and I cannot accept the intervention of any Stranger, while there are four heads of Departments with all of whom I am upon terms of social acquaintance, and through whom, if he desires a reconciliation with me, he can make his wish known— I told him of the overture by Coll. R. M. Johnson in April 1832 and of that by R. Rush in 1833—and of my reasons for declining both; which were that he had in the first place omitted to visit me, when he came here in February 1829. and while I was President; and secondly that he had in his inaugural address, made charges before the world against my administration of interfering with the freedom of Elections, and of wasteful extravagance requiring the searching process of reform
which he could not then know to be true, and which he must now know to be false— He has done me wrong in the face of the world— Richard M. Johnson told me that his reason for not visiting me in February 1829 was because he had been made to believe that I had caused or countenanced the libellous newspaper publication about his wife— Johnson told me that the President then, in April 1832. was satisfied that he had been misinformed at the time when he had entertained those suspicions of me, and that I never had countenanced those publications He proposed to me that the President should give me an invitation to dinner, as a member of Congress— I said that would be a civility but no reparation— He asked if I would accept an invitation to a private and select party— I said there was the same objection to that— Johnson then asked me what I would wish— I said nothing— If the President was convinced he had wronged me, it was for him to make reparation as he thought fit— I asked nothing— If he was not so convinced, there was no basis for a restoration of social intercourse between us
7. VI. Monday.
Mrs Wolfenden came and settled her account for Rent to the 1st. of January last— At the

House the Speaker brought up the motion of J. M. Patton to suspend the rules, to enable him to move for leave to withdraw the Resolutions of the Legislature of Virginia, heretofore presented by him, and referred to the select Committee on the Slavery abolition memorials— The question was twice put and no Quorum answered. I moved that the motion to suspend the rules be laid on the table and the yeas and nays were called—my motion was rejected 80 to 83—then the motion to suspend the Rules was rejected 68 to 96— Then a motion was made to suspend the Rules to proceed on the report of the Committee of Elections, and rejected— Then a motion to admit Resolutions of Inquiry with Petitions and Memorials not adopted— At last the call for Petitions came beginning with Maine— I presented four Petitions— 1. of Thomas and Ralph Harkins (given me by L. Jarvis)—referred to the Committee of Ways and Means— 2. of W. S. Nicholls and others of Georgetown, praying an act of incorporation, for a Cotton manufacture—referred to the Committee of Manufactures 3. of William M. Stokes, heir or representative of John Stokes, an Officer of the Virginia Continental line in the Revolutionary War, given me by Mr Hoard, introduced to me by J. M. Patton—referred to Committee on Revolutionary claims. 4. Petition of G. H. Osborn and 167. citizens of Poughkeepsie for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia—referred to the Select Committee on Slavery in the District— The Call for Petitions went through all the States and Territories— J. Robertson offered a Resolution of enquiry by the Committee on the District of Columbia, looking to the recession of the District to the States of Virginia and Maryland
Motion to suspend the Rules—no quorum voting— Call of the House commenced and suspended— Suspension of the Rules by yeas and nays, rejected 71 to 114.

Mr Newland the Petitioner of the contested North-Carolina election called me out and thanked me for the remarks that I made on Saturday upon the decision of the house against allowing him to be heard by Counsel upon his claim to his Seat, but he said he was so anxious to have the question settled, that he did not wish to have the decision of the house reversed— He wanted to know as soon as possible whether he was entitled to the seat or not— After the adjournment I went over to Persico’s chamber and viewed his models, of Columbus and Amerigo Vespucci. Governor Lincoln was there; and General Aaron Ward, and his brother in Law, son of Elkanah Watson— Lincoln and Ward are members of the Select Committee on the Public Offices— I objection to any Statue in honour of Amerigo, and advised Persico, rather to take a founder of Settlements, such as Sir Walter Raleigh for his second group— Ward and Watson, I took to their lodgings at Gadsby’s— Persico came this Evening, and told me that he would make a model of Raleigh—
8. VI. Tuesday.

Met the Committee of Manufactures—present Adams, Denny, Dickerson, Granger, Holsey, Judson, Lee— Absent M’Comas and Webster— The Committee postponed the subject of reducing the duties as proposed by the Secretary of the Treasury, to wait for the action of the Senate thereon— The subject of reducing the duties on Brown Linens was also postponed— The Chairman was instructed to move a Resolution for printing 25000 copies of the Letter from the Secretary of the Treasury, upon the cultivation and manufacture of Cotton, with tabular Statements— Then adjourned to Thursday Morning.

At the House— A Motion was made to suspend the Rules, to receive reports from standing Committees—to which were added the proposal for offering Resolutions—not carried— Jarvis moved to suspend the rules to offer a Resolution for adjourning to two O’Clock to-morrow to give opportunity to the members of the House to attend the launch of the frigate Columbia— There were several efforts to take the question by yeas and nays; all of which failed— An Amendment was moved and carried that the adjournment should be till Thursday— Then the North-Carolina contested election came up— Spangler of Ohio had moved yesterday a reconsideration of the vote refusing the admission of Counsel for the petitioner—and made a short speech in support of his motion. Grennell began a speech against reconsideration but was arrested by the expiration of the first hour.— The motion was then made to continue the discussion—but failed— Then the rule was suspended to take up the New-York fire bill— The Previous Question was moved, but withdrawn—and a sharp debate arose in which D. J. Pearce—Sutherland and Judson— Also Underwood and Chambers of Kentucky—
9. VI. Wednesday—

Launch of the frigate Columbia— I took my two Granddaughters Mary-Louisa and Georgiana Frances with Mrs Goode their nurse, to see the launch of the frigate Columbia at the Navy-yard— We saw the launch from the shore, and it was made in very handsome style— We met there several members of Congress—Granger, Lane, Sutherland, Parks, F. O. J. Smith and Preston of the Senate— Immediately after the launch which was about a quarter of an hour before noon, we returned— The Senate were in Session— I stopped at the U.S. Branch Bank that was and took my balanced Book— On the 3d. of this month the Charter of the Bank of the United States expired— The mother Bank at Philadelphia has received a new Charter from the Legislature of Pennsylvania— I called twice at the Offices of the Secretaries of War and of the Navy; but the first time they had not returned from the launch and the second they had gone home— At the Pension Office I left Leavitt Lane’s Affidavit to obtain for him a new Pension Certificate and at the Bounty Land Office I left the Letter ofHitchcock containing enquiries which Mr Gordon the clerk in that office will answer— I returned by card the visit of the Spanish Minister, Calderon de la Barca. Mary spent the afternoon and evening at Mrs W. S. Smiths Mr Charles M. Watson, brought me a Letter from his father Elkanah Watson.
10. VI. Thursday.

Met the Committee of Manufactures—present Adams, Denny, Dickerson, Granger, Holsey, Lee, Judson, Webster There was some desultory conversation, upon the Bill for repealing the provisos in the Tariff Act, and the substitute proposed by Mr Dickerson, but there was some question made by G. Lee, whether the subject was properly referred to the Committee not settled— The Petition from Georgetown for an Act of incorporation, for a cotton manufacturer was considered, and some discussion and much division of opinion, upon the question whether any such act of incorporation should be granted—

In the House the first hour was devoted to the contested North-Carolina election— Grennell finished his speech against the reconsideration of the vote refusing Counsel to the Petitioner— Miller of Pennsylvania spoke in favour of the reconsideration, and Antony against it— Bouldin rose to speak, but the hour had expired and the order of the day was called— Dunlap moved to suspend the rules to take up a land Bill of Tennessee—it failed— But the rules were suspended, to take up the Bill providing for the payment of the Volunteers in the Indian war in Florida. Committee of the whole on the State of the Union J. Y. Mason in the Chair— The debate was on a Section added by the Senate for the appointment of 3 additional Paymasters—
11. VI. Friday.

At the House the motion of Jenifer to suspend the rules for him to offer a Resolution, referring to the Committee on Post-Offices and Post-Roads, an enquiry concerning the establishment a new Post Road, was rejected by yeas and nays.—

I asked the consent of the House, to report from the Committee of Manufactures, the Resolution to print 25000 copies of the Letter of the Secretary of the Treasury and tables respecting the cultivation and manufacture of Cotton, for the use of the house—objection was made— I moved the suspension of the rule which was carried, and by consent of the house the Resolution was now considered.— Lewis Williams moved as an amendment10000 copies rejected—Dunlap moved an amendment, that the report of the Committee of the last Session on the West Point Academy—be also taken from the files and 10000 copies be printed— The Speaker declared this motion to be not in order; Lewis Williams moved an amendment 15000 copies which was carried— Jarvis then moved a reconsideration of the vote refusing the suspension of the Rule for Jenifer to offer his Resolution— The consideration of this motion was postponed— The North-Carolina election then came up, and Grennell finished his Bouldin made a speech in favour of reconsidering. Huntsman moved the Previous Question, but the Speaker said the main question would not only carry with it the motion of reconsideration, but the amendment itself proposing the admission of Counsel, and would be on the Resolution offered by Hard for the petitioner’s admission into the House to sustain his claim— Huntsman withdrew his motion— Bynum and Hard continued the debate till the hour expired— Bynum moved to suspend the order of the day to continue the debate—vote by count 101 to 51—then by tellers 104 to 53. not two thirds— Orders of the day— Several Bills from the Senate read twice and committed— Joint Resolution for relief of Benedict Alford and Rush—long debate—
12. VI. Saturday—

Took the two children with me to the Capitol— At the house, the contested North-Carolina Election consumed the day. The first question was on the motion to reconsider the vote refusing the request of the Petitioner to be heard by Counsel. Hard made a speech of about an hour against it reconsideration, which was refused by yeas and nays 91 to 97.— The hour had expired, and a motion was made to suspend the rules to continue the consideration of this subject, which was carried by yeas and nays:The motions pending were that the consideration of the subject should be postponed to the 2d. and 6th. of March—both days already past. The motions were withdrawn— Then came the motion to recommit the Report to the Committee to give the sitting member further time to take additional testimony— This was debated by Maury of Tennessee, Boyd of Kentucky and Sampson Mason of Ohio, D. J. Pearce, and Graham the sitting member— David Newlan the Petitioner was admitted within the Bar and made a short address to the house.
Persico—Luigi—called this Evening—has made a new model.
Adams Joseph Harrod Midshipman arrived this Evening.

Henry Hubbard now a Senator from New-Hampshire, was in the house I spoke to him upon a Resolution, that he has offered in the Senate, in favour of the Revolutionary Pensioners of 1818. struck from the lists, similar to that which I have offered in the House— He says the Senate Committee on Revolutionary Pensions are not favourable to the Resolution; but that he will nevertheless press it upon the Senate— I spoke to him also of the lost fortification Bill— He says, that he voted on the Cumberland road Bill, before going to the Conference, with the Committee on the part of the Senate, after voting on the Cumberland road Bill—and he referred to French a Clerk of the House, who was at the Clerk’s table, when the Committee of Conference was appointed and remembers the facts in exact concurrence with Hubbard— Met the Committee of Manufactures this morning, Denny, Dickerson, Holsey, Lee—absent Granger, M’Comas, Judson and Webster— No business done— Adjourned to Tuesday 15. March.
13. VI. Sunday.
Heard at the Presbyterian Church Mr Gallaudet from John 14.14.

Mr Bishop was there as a hearer, and I wished he had been in the Pulpit— Gallaudet is too tedious— After Church I called at Mrs Latimer’s and gave Alexander H Everett a Letter from my Son Charles which I had received for him this morning— Mr and Mrs Frye and their son Thomas dined and spent the Evening with us— Alexander H. Everett came in the Evening and left Charles’s Letter with me— It gives an account of the movements of parties in Boston towards the Presidential Election and the management of the Government— Everett told me that he had been last Evening at the President’s, and that he spoke with much satisfaction of the speech that I made on the lost fortification Bill, and said he heard I was in the habit of keeping a Diary— I think it must have been Vanderpoel, must have told him this— My nephew Midshipman Joseph Harrod Adams is with us— He came up last Night from Norfolk where he arrived in the Line of Battleship Delaware, in which he has been nearly four years on a cruize in the Mediterranean, under Commodore Patterson— In the course of this time they have visited Spain, France, Italy, the Barbary Coast, the Grecian Islands, Constantinople, and the Holy Land— He gave me a cane, made of a twig from an Olive tree, cut upon the mount of Olives—
14. VI. Monday.

Sleepless Night— I know not why— Left Joseph H. Adams at Gadsby’s— At the House— Petitions were called immediately after the reading of the Journal; Resolutions of the Legislature of New-York, had been some time since presented to the House calling upon Congress to new organized the Militia— Gillett had moved to refer the Resolutions to the Committee on the Militia with sundry Instructions—and the debate on it had been deferred to this day— Gillett supported his motion by a Speech—he was followed by L. Phelps who moved as an amendment an additional Instruction, that the Militia as now organized should be paid, when called out to train— Glascock says the whole subject is before the Committee on the Militia who will report in 8 or 10 days— L. Lincoln makes a Speech against the Instruction offered by Phelps and in favour of the Instructions proposed by Gillett— Hamer moves to lay the whole subject on the table—which is carried—then followed a memorial from Dauphin County Pennsylvania, presented by a member from New-York, praying an appropriation for the colonization Society, and a motion to refer to a Committee— Motion to lay the Motion on the table carried by yeas and nays 129 to 69— Petitions then called for, commencing with Maine— I had the petition praying for buoys in the harbour of Mattapoisett, taken from the files and referred to the Committee on Commerce— Howard presented a Petition from labourers on the roads praying for the establishment of a ten hour system for works on the public account— Motion to lay on the table made and withdrawn— Motions to refer to the Committee on Roads and Canals, on the Judiciary, and to a select Committee debate arising the subject was deferred to next Monday.
15. VI. Tuesday.

Met the Committee of Manufactures—present Adams, Denny, Dickerson, Granger, Holsey, Judson, M’Comas—absent Lee and Webster— I was instructed to report a Bill, to incorporate the Georgetown manufacturing company— The Letters to the Secretary of the Treasury to Cambreleng and to A. Lawrence from New-York against the duties on stained Linens, were read and I was instructed to report against the repeal of those duties— I mentioned the application to Me of Mr King of Alabama in favour of the Bill from the Senate for remitting the duties upon iron materials for an iron boat; but the Committee declined altering their decision against the Bill— At the House John Bell of Tennessee asked the unanimous consent of the House to offer a Resolution that the house should hereafter meet at 11. O’Clock—objection was made, and he asked a suspension of the Rules, and the yeas and nays. It was carried by a vote ofHardin moved an amendment from and after the first of April—rejected— Hawes moved to postpone the question till next Monday—rejected The resolution was carried—A motion was made to suspend the rules to consider the report on the North-Carolina election but it failed— Beardsley moved to suspend the rules for him to make Reports from the judiciary Committee, but it failed— The Navy Appropriation Bill was brought up and considered in Committee of the whole on the Union, Miller of Pennsylvania in the Chair— Evans of Maine, made a Speech of two hours against Bell’s motion to strike out half the appropriation for the Navy-Yard at Portsmouth New-Hampshire, and chiefly in answer to Waddy Thompson’s Speech— Chambers of Pennsylvania took the floor after Evans, and moved the Committee to rise— The house adjourned about 4. O’Clock— I went over the Square to Persico’s chambers and saw his new model of Sir Walter Raleigh to match his Columbus, but too much like it— Walk home—
16. VI. Wednesday.

Mr Fendall called on me this morning and mentioned that he was in want of an accommodation for 6 and 8 Months of 800 dollars— I told him I would ascertain whether I can assist him in this matter and will do so if possible— A person came with proposals for a reprint of Blackwood’s Magazine which I declined— I attended the House precisely at 11. O’Clock— G. Evans objected to the reading of the Journal until it should be ascertained that there is a Quorum present— There was then a call at the House to which on the first call 159. members answered to their names— Several attempts were made to suspend the call all of which failed until a full hour had expired— Then a motion was made to suspend the rules, to devote the day to the contested North-Carolina Election—failed by yeas and nays 115 to 67. not two thirds— The navy Appropriation Bill was taken up, in Committee of the whole on the Union— Hamer of Ohio on the Union— Chambers of Pennsylvania made a Speech in favour of the Appropriation—followed by Bell of Tennessee, who now withdrew his motion to reduce by one half the appropriation for the Navy-Yard at Portsmouth New-Hampshire, and moved to strike out the whole of that appropriation and made another speech in support of this new motion—
17. VI. Thursday.

Call at the Metropolis Bank, and left Midshipman Joseph H. Adams at Gadsby’s— At the House,made a motion to suspend the rules for the reception of the reports of Committees—and Hawes moved to suspend the rules to take up his motion for investigating the West-Point Academy—but both motions failed— The contested North-Carolina election then came up; and the Petitioner David Newlan addressed the house on the application of the sitting member for further time to take testimony— He was followed by Graham, Boyd, Hard and Howard and others—till one O’Clock—a motion was made to continue the discussion; but it failed— The Navy Appropriation bill was resumed, in Committee of the whole on the Union, Hamer in the chair, and Bell continued his Speech against the Bill—
18. IV. Friday.

Rose at four O’Clock, and wrote three hours before breakfast— After breakfast I went with Joseph H. Adams to the Secretary of the Navy, to whom I introduced him— I left with Mr Dickerson two Letters for Midshipman John Quincy Adams, and spoke to him in behalf of Mr Ebenezer Gay’s Son for an appointment of Master’s Mate, and in behalf of Levi Lincoln junr for an appointment as a Lieutenant in the Marine Corps— The Secretary said that they made now no appointments of Master’s Mates, nor of sailing Masters; the duties of those Officers being now performed by Passed Midshipmen, and that the transfer from Midshipman to Lieutt in the Marine Corps was not admissible, there being moreover no vacancy now in the Marine Corps— I found the House in Session and the contested North Carolina Election under discussion— Hard of New-York for the minority and Boyd of Kentucky for the Majority of the Committee occupied the hour in altercation whether the report of the Committee should be recommitted for the sitting member to have more time to take testimony Rencher made a speech on the qualifications of voters by the Laws of North Carolina— At Noon a motion was made to suspend the rules to continue the debate; but failed as usual for want of two thirds— Private business taken up— Joint Resolution for relief of Benedict Alford and Robert Brush: a debate of three hours upon propositions to correct a mistake by which a Bill that passed the House and was indefinitely postponed was by inadvertence presented to the President was signed by him and published as a Law— At last, after failing in several previous attempts, I moved a simple reference to the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions with Instructions to report a Bill which was carried, and the House adjourned Carolina de Wint and Thomas J. Frye dined with us.

div.p: 19. V. Saturday.

Visits last Evening of Mr Connell and of Mr Langtree of Georgetown to whom I gave my remarks upon the personations of Shakespear and upon the character of Desdemona— This morning I wrote with a crippled forefinger of the right-hand till breakfast time— Visits this morning from a man named Patterson, who wishes to apply for a Patent, for his brother an Irishman belonging to Dublin— It is an invention for dying hides without use of Oak-bark— His brother at an expense of five hundred pounds Sterling has taken out Patents for all the British Dominions. I told him he must prepare a memorial to Congress setting forth the reasons which should induce them to grant a patent to a foreigner residing in a foreign country— Also from A. H. Everett and Mr Schermerhorn, who enquired whether, a Bill had been reported for the admission of Arkansas into the Union— The report has not yet been made, but is ready— Mr Schermerhorn advised special attention to the Western Boundary, as in the Bill to be reported, that it may not interfere with the Indian boundaries.

I found the house taking the yeas and nays upon a question for a call of the house, I was too late in for my name to be taken. A quorum answered, and the vote against the call prevailed. The questions upon the contested North Carolina election were taken up, and Rencher finished his Speech, against the report of the Committee of Elections and for allowing the sitting member time to take further testimony— The petitioner David Newland replied and a long debate followed— The rules were suspended to continue the discussion, and finally the motion for allowance of time was rejected by yeas and nays 103 to 87. The report was then made the special order of the day for next Thursday, and the parts of the Constitution and Laws of North-Carolina, relating to Elections are to be printed.
20. V. Sunday—

My disabled finger is disheartening, and puts my philosophy to the test. Mr Woodbury the Secretary of the Treasury and wished for a Resolution to be adopted by the House authorising him to insert additional notes to the report and tabular statements upon the cultivation of cotton which by a Resolution of the House offered by order of the Committee of Manufactures, are to be printed under his directed— He left me a Resolution ready drawn— Mr Woodbury invited me to dine with him next Saturday and I accepted his invitation.

Mary with the two children, Caroline de Wint and the Midshipman went to the Capitol and heard Mr Stockton— I attended morning and afternoon at St. John’s Church, where Mr Hawley read prayers for the fifth Sunday in Lent, and preached in the morning from Titus 2.10. That they may adorn the doctrine of God our Saviour in all things; and in the afternoon from Psalm 23.1. The Lord is my shepherd: I shall not want.
21. V. Monday.

At the House, the first business takes up, was a motion, of Chilton Allan, to refer Resolutions of the Legislature of Kentucky, recommending a distribution of the proceeds of the Public Lands among the several States, according to their respective federal population, to a Select Committee to report a Bill— The Resolutions were presented last Monday, and the debate was turned over to this day.— Mr Allan commenced a Speech against the present Administration which at one O’Clock was arrested and after an effort to suspend the rules to continue the discussion, which failed it was postponed again till next Monday— Then the States were called over for Petitions— I presented two petitions from Hanover and one from Hanson for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave-trade in the District of Columbia—referred to the Select Committee— A Petition from John Watson of Connecticut for indemnity for a vessel built by him for the public service, and burnt by the enemy in 1814—referred to the Committee of Claims.— I presented also the Resolution yesterday left with me by Mr Woodbury, which was adopted—and a Resolution instructing the Committee of foreign Relations to enquire and report on the expediency of allowing additional compensation to Daniel Brent Consul at Paris, which I introduced at the request of his brother, William Brent, and which was adopted— Petitions, Resolutions and Reports of standing Committees were all gone through, and the House adjourned after four O’Clock. I was so unwell with a severe stricture across the breast and oppressive catarrhal cough that Dr Huntt was sent for and prescribed a vapour stool and warm draughts which I took, and an early bed— Caroline de Wint here.
22. V:30. Tuesday.

I rose between three and four O’Clock partly relieved from the threatening stricture over my breast; but returned to bed, and rose again at half past five—read in Sir James Mackintosh’s abridged History the account of Anne Boleyn’s downfall and execution—and heard the two children read— Doctor Huntt came while we were at Breakfast. At the House immediately after the reading of the Journal—the Speaker announced the motion of Cambreleng from the Committee of Ways and Means to discharge the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union from the consideration of the Bill for repealing the section of the Act for chartering the Bank of the United States, which makes the notes of the Bank receivable in payments of the revenue— I enquired how this had preference over other and elder unfinished business— He said that reports of the Committees took precedence of other resolutions— I then renewed the objection I had made yesterday to taking this subject from the Committee of the whole on the Union into the House and a debate commenced, and continued till one O’Clock when the House passed to the orders of the day— The navy appropriation Bill—on which Mr Bell continued his Speech tillO’Clock and left it still unfinished.
Met the Committee of Manufactures—present Adams, Denny, Dickerson, Granger, Lee, Judson, and Webster— Sundry Letters were read and subjects: partially discussed, and all postponed—
23. V:45. Wednesday—

Mr Frye called this morning, for conversation upon various private concerns— He gave me a check on the late branch Bank for 150 dollars for a half years rent of the mills— He spoke also of the question respecting the distribution of T. J. Hellen’s Estate— I thought whatever the Law might be, that by agreement Walter should be admitted to his share of the Estate—

At the House, the Motion of Mr Cambreleng as Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, that the Bill to repeal of the Section of the United States Bank Charter Law, which made the Bills of the Bank receivable in the collection of the revenue—be transferred from the Committee of the whole on the Union to the House, was taken up and debated till the previous question was called by R. Boon of Indiana and carried; the main question was put and carried by yeas and nays.

Cambreleng offered a Letter to be read, from Boston, purporting that the U.S. Branch Bank at Boston refuses to pay any Bills, except its own.— Patton asked what question was before the house. The Speaker said the Committee of the whole house on the Union, having been discharged from the consideration of the Bill, it would be in the House, as if it had been never referred. I asked what would be the state of the Bill in the order of business. The Speaker said it would go over till to-morrow, and then he should call for Reports from Committees. Cambreleng called for the reading of the Letters— I said if the Letter should be read it would be debatable and I should have some observations on it to make. The order of the day was called—the House went into Committee of the whole on the Union Hamer in the Chair on the Navy Appropriation Bill. Bell of Tennessee finished his four days speech— Dr Hall the Mineralogical Lecturer came and asked for the Letter which I promised him to D. Brent I asked him to come again for it Saturday Evening—
24 V:30 Thursday

Very unwell in the Night, and all this day by a severe return of Cold and Catarrh. Mr Fendall called upon me this morning and I was obliged to decline accommodating him with the loan he had requested—the Columbian College still failing to pay the interest of their debt to me— Mr Patterson came about his memorial to Congress for a Patent for his brother for his invention of tanning with oak bark— He asked my opinion as to the success, which I could not give him, but advised him to prepare his memorial, and promised to present it.

At the house I met Mr Edward Blake, who told me he should leave the City to-morrow to return homeward— The Speaker told me that the Bill discharged from the Committee of the whole gained thereby no precedence in the order of business of the House without a farther vote of the House— He called for Reports from Standing Committees which occupied the first hour— Then the special order of the day was the North Carolina Election— Boyd the Reporter of the Committee moved a suspension of the rules, to devote to-morrow and the next day, as well as this day to the discussion of this Subject which was carried— The Committee reported a Resolution that David Newland was entitled to the Seat— Graham moved as an amendment, that certain testimony in his favour taken since the Committee refused him further time to take evidence should be received— This gave rise to a debate of 3 hours—and the house adjourned— When I got home I found Caroline de Wint was gone, in the rail-road Cars which left the City at four O’Clock for Baltimore— She went with Mr W. S Smith, suddenly summoned home by Letter from her father on account of illness of her mother— Mary dined out, at Mrs Smith’s— I was very much indisposed this Evening and disqualified for writing— I read some pages of the Memoir of the Life, writings and Speeches of Sir James Mackintosh— My right hand yet crippled—
25. V:30. Friday

Another restless, feverish, and almost sleepless Night. Up between three and four O’Clock, and returned to bed— Rose again at half past five, but unable to write, read in Sir James Mackintosh’s abridged history, and in the Memoir of his Life. Mr Cass called on me, and asked me if I would dine with him some day next week, which I promise, if the state of my health shall admit— He said he would send me a note—

At the House, Reports of standing Committees were called. among them Hiland Hall of Vermont—from the Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads, asked leave of the House to make a report from the Minority of the Committee, stating that the majority of the Committee had some weeks since laid the subject on the table and that they would probably make no report— Objection was made, and the Speaker decided that it was not in order for the minority of a Committee to make a report without special permission from the house, and advised Hall to ask the suspension of the Rules, to enable him to offer the report. Hall said that he was not satisfied with the decision of the Speaker, but would submit to it. He moved to suspend the rules, but his motion was rejected without division— Under evident excitement of the Slave representation— The report is an argument against the Constitutional power of Congress to pass any such Law as was recommended by the President. At Noon the North-Carolina contested election was taken up, and Speeches were made by Hard—Boyd—Hoare—Beardsley—Wise—Anthony—Balie Peyton, until past four O’Clock when the house adjourned— I continued severely indisposed, unable to read or write all the Evening Mr George Bancroft was here this Evening; and with him I had much political conversation— At the close of the Evening I took a warm foot-bath steeped with mustard-seed—
26. VI:30. Saturday

A more quiet Night, and some sleep— Rose after Sunrise with both my hands still disabled— And the cattarhal fever somewhat abated— Midshipman Joseph H. Adams rode with me partly to the Capitol; and he left us to go this afternoon to Baltimore on his way home to his mother. It was half past 11. when I reached the house—which was in Session, and receiving reports from standing Committees— At Noon the orders of the day were called, and the contested North Carolina Election was resumed. Rencher moved eight new resolutions, for admitting the testimony recently received, and for striking off votes counted for the petitioner, and restoring to Graham votes, struck off from his poll by the Committee— This was debated by Rencher, Bynum Hardin, Mercer, M’Kay, Hamer, and Graves of Kentucky— Then at 4. O’Clock a motion was made to adjourn and failed. Then a motion to suspend the orders of business till this question shall be decided which failed— Then a motion to adjourn taken by yeas and nays and rejected 83 to 110. Then Mercer moved a suspension of the rules to enable him to offer a Resolution that this subject should have precedence of all other business on Monday and Tuesday next after twelve O’Clock; rejected by yeas and nays 96 to 92 not two thirds, Graves continued his Speech, a very heated one till between 10 and 11. O’Clock amidst motions to adjourn repeatedtimes, and rejected by yeas and nays, averaging a minority from 70 to 80 and a majority from 95 to 110— I had engaged to dine at Mr Woodbury’s. Between 7 and 8 in the Evening Ward came to my Seat, and told me he had returned from the dinner, and had made my excuses— I wrote a note of excuse, and sent Wilson with it to Mr Woodbury, and told him to come back for me with the Carriage between 9 and 10— As Graves sat down after his six hours speech John Calhoun of Kentucky rose and addressed the Speaker— Cushman of New-Hampshire rose at the same instant and moved the previous Question, which Graves had given notice that he would do— But Calhoun was too quick for him and the Speaker gave Calhoun the floor. He spoke vehemently till midnight.
27.— To bed IV:45— Rose VII:30. Sunday.

Precisely as the Hands of the Clock in the House of Representatives, were at the point of XII Joab Lawler a member of the House from Alabama, rose in his place and interrupting Calhoun who was speaking enquired as a question of order; whether the House would continue in Session, on the Sabbath, there being no urgent necessity requiring it— The Speaker, referring to two or three prior precedents of Sunday Morning Sessions—the first of which was at the Session of the 19th Congress, decided that it was in order to continue in Session from which decision Lawler appealed and made a few remarks in support of his appeal— I immediately rose and said that approving entirely the appeal, but foreseeing that it might itself defeat the purpose of the mover by exciting a debate till the morning dawn, I should close the few remarks that I had to make, with a motion to adjourn. I then stated that in a case of urgent necessity, the house had frequently continued in Session, until the morning of the Sabbath; and that on the 3d. of March 1805 both Houses of Congress had sitten the whole day, as numerous Statutes enacted and dated on that day would prove— But the rule was to adjourn from Saturday till Monday—the exception was to sit in cases of urgent necessity— This was not the present case, and if any motion to adjourn should fail I should ask the member from Alabama to reduce his appeal to writing, with the express negation of a necessity for sitting. My motion to adjourn failed by a vote of 83 to 95—upon which Lawler reduced his appeal to writing as I had desired. He was proceeding to speak on his appeal, when Hawes moved to lay the Appeal on the table; but the Speaker said Lawler had the floor— As soon as he finished I objected to the motion to lay the appeal on the table as nugatory, and gave notice that it being Sunday I should hold myself bound, by none of the rules of the House unless and until there should be a positive vote of a majority of the House of the necessity for a Sunday Session; and that I hoped there would be a sufficient number of the minority of my opinion to leave the majority without a Quorum— The hint was taken, and on the second for the previous Question, by
Tellers there were 93 in favour and only 19. against taking the main question— A motion was then made to adjourn and the yeas and nays were called. My name was twice called and I did not answer— Several of the subsequent names were called and answered: when Wise rose and stated that I was in my Seat, and had not answered— The Speaker read the rule requiring every member present to vote upon every question unless excused by the House, but said that the time for requiring my vote was when my name was called, and that others having been called since, the time for making the question had passed away— Wise renewed his remark when his own name was called— Hawes moved that I should be excused from voting; but I said I did not ask to be excused—that it being the Sabbath day, and there being no urgent necessity for the Session of the House, I did not hold myself bound by the rules of the House, the rule of usage being that unless for business of urgent necessity the House do not sit on Sunday’s. Hawes withdrew his motion— Wise insisted upon his objection— Beardsley renewed the motion that I should be excused on the ground of consciencious scruples— I disclaimed this motive and said I would sit and vote till another midnight, if by an explicit vote of the house it should be declared a necessity for sitting on Sunday— Beardsley finally withdrew his motion. Mercer moved that I should not be required to vote— Wise moved that I should be compelled to vote— Balie Peyton, Wise and Bynum made fiery Speeches and it came to a furious personal quarrel, and shaking of fists and d—d rascals and scoundrels, and puppies passed between them— Then Mercer commenced his part as Peacemaker, and after much coaxing and intreaty Bynum and Wise with not absolute good grace pledged themselves not to pursue the quarrel further— It was finally agreed to resume the Subject Monday and Tuesday, and the House at half past four A.M. adjourned. Jarvis and Gorham Parks went home with me— It was five O’Clock, and full dawn of day when I found my bed; but no sleep— I rose again at 8.

Attended Church this morning at the Presbyterian Church, and heard Mr Gallaudet the father from Romans 8:34 [“]Who is he that condemneth? It is Christ that died, yea rather that is risen again, who is even at the right hand of God, who also maketh intercession for us.”— And in the afternoon with my grand-child Mary-Louisa, where Mr Hawley read the Evening service for the Sunday before Easter and preached from Job 31.13. “If I did despise the cause of my man servant or my maid-servant, when they contended with me. 14 What then shall I do when God riseth up? and when he visiteth, what shall I answer him?” The agitations of the Night and the loss of night’s repose, disabled me from due attention to the services of the day; and I find myself with an extraordinary hoarseness and almost extinction of voice.
28. V:30. Monday.

Sore throat—Catarrhal fever; and an eruption just below the calf of my left leg, in addition to one on the forefinger of my right hand and one on the middle finger of my left hand. At the House— Petition day; but no Petitions were presented. Chilton Allan concluded his Speech upon the Resolutions of the Legislature of Kentucky, recommending the distribution of the proceeds of the public Lands among the States in the ratio of their federal population— Hawes of Kentucky commenced a Speech in opposition to that of his colleague; but was arrested at one O’Clock, when the special order, the North-Carolina election was resumed— John Calhoun of Kentucky finished the Speech, which he had begun Saturday Night— After which Mr. Graham in a speech of two hours maintained his own cause and proved satisfactorily to me his title to his Seat— Mr Newland then rose in support of his Petition—but it was four O’Clock, and the house adjourned Samuel Beardsley was in the house this morning, but left the City in the Baltimore Cars at 4. this afternoon— Appointed Attorney-General of the State of New-York— Philemon Dickerson a member of the House from New-Jersey also left the City this afternoon.
29. VI. Tuesday.

A Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures was called for this morning, but the only members besides myself who attended were Denny, Holsey, and Granger, not a Quorum— Mr. Littlefield of New-York, attended and made observations upon the subject of the brown linens— Mr Littlefield promised to send further samples—a Letter praying for a duty upon pins, or an exemption from duty upon brass wire was read— Adjourned to Saturday next— In the House Fairfield from the Committee on the District of Columbia, reported a Bill to incorporate the Jackson City in the District of Columbia—objection was made to the second reading of the Bill—which gave rise to a short and sharp debate— Reed moved to lay the Bill on the Table— Two calls for the yeas and nays were made and failed first, no Quorum answering, and the second time less than one fifth of the members voting demanded it—but the Bill was laid on the table by a vote of 80. to 64— Several Bills from the Senate were read twice and referred— A Bill for establishing the Northern boundary of Ohio— Vinton made a short Speech urging that it should pass to a third reading without reference to a Committee— Thomas rose to object to this, but the hour of Noon was come—and the North-Carolina election was called— The Petitioner David Newland spoke about one hour in support of his claim to the Seat, immediately after which Cushman moved the Previous Question, upon the Resolutions reported by the Committee; and thereupon Balie Peyton, moved a Resolution to recommit the report to be perfected, there being as he contended no report before the House. Hence a violent and most disorderly debate of 3 hours upon points of order, decisions of the Speaker and appeals. The Previous question, was finally driven through— The Resolution of the Committee of Elections declaring Graham not entitled to the Seat, agreed to 114 to 87. The Resolution declaring Newland entitled to the Seat rejected 100 to 99. A Resolution declaring the Seat vacated, and that the Speaker inform the Governor of North-Carolina of the fact was then adopted and the house at 6. O’Clock adjourned—

div.p: 30. IV:30. Wednesday—

Awoke with a heavy oppression upon the lungs, and the perpetually recurring and exhausting, catarrhal cough, and rose, and read in the Memoir of the Life of Sir James Mackintosh. Then wrote—heard the children read, breakfasted, and attended the House— Immediately after the reading the Journal Balie Peyton, made some objection to the accuracy of the Journal, and moved some correction or alteration— After nearly an hour of debates the Journal was left without alteration— Reports from standing Committees were called, and then there was a Report by Dromgoole, from the select Committee, on the recommendation by the President of an Amendment of the Constitution, in the election of President and Vice-President, and a substitute proposed by Dromgoole himself who dissented from the joint Resolution, proposed by the majority of the Committee— Then another hour of debate on the question of fixing a particular day for the debate—left undecided— W. B. Shepard from the Committee on the District of Columbia moved that the 27th. and 28th. of April should be set apart for business relating to the District—more debate—29. and 30 moved as substitutes—then the 28th. and 29th. then the 28th. only—and at last laid on the Table— Then a question whether a Bill from the Senate authorising the location of certain State railways through the Public Lands should be referred to the Committee on the Public Lands, or to the Committee on Roads and Canals— By the vote, the reference was to the Committee of the Public Lands. order of the day— Committee of the whole on the Union— Hamer in the Chair upon the Navy Appropriation Bill—Garland made a Speech of 2 hours in reply to Thompson of S. Carolina, Evans of Maine and Bell of Tennessee. The House adjourned at 1/2 past 3. I went into the Senate, where they were debating on a Bill for the admission of Michigan into the Union— They adjourned at 1/2 past four— A. H. Everett spent two hours of the Evening with me— He intends leaving the City to return home next Friday.
31. VI. Thursday.

Rose after Sunrise—with the breast somewhat relieved from the oppression of the Catarrhal cough and hoarseness of the last week— At the House the Committee of Elections reported a Resolution, directing the Clerk of the House to pay David Newland compensation as a member until the decision of the House against him— A debate followed wasting the time of the House till one O’Clock, when the Previous Question was moved— The Speaker passed to the orders of the day—but on motion the Rules were suspended by a vote of more than two thirds, to conclude the subject. There was a second to the previous Question, which was carried by yeas and naysand the Resolution was adopted by a vote oftoI voted for it though I thought the Appropriation should have been made by Law— This was more strongly apparent because in the partial Appropriation Act for the payment of the expenses of the two Houses of Congress at this Session, there is an express proviso that the item of Contingencies shall be confined to the ordinary current expenses of the Houses— Notwithstanding which, the Resolution was adopted— At near two O’Clock the Order of the day was resumed—the House went into Committee of the whole on the Union, Hamer in the Chair, on the Navy Appropriation Bill, and Garland of Virginia concluded his Speech on Bell’s motion to strike out the appropriation of 60000 dollars for the Navy-Yard at Portsmouth, upon which he went through the whole range in defence of the Administration against Waddy Thompson, Evans and Bell of Tennessee— Garland closed after 4. O’Clock, and Jarvis of five competitors obtained the floor— The Committee rose and the House adjourned. In the Evening I had a visit from MrBridge, a son of my old Classmate and friend James Bridge—deceased. He is returning from a visit to the Island of Cuba, with his wife to his residence at Augusta, Maine.
